item.title: Imposition of Tariffs on Canadian Products to Address Drug Trafficking Concerns
item.description: This executive order expands a national emergency related to illegal drugs and immigration, imposing a 25% tariff on products from Canada to mitigate the flow of illicit drugs into the U.S. The order cites concerns over drug trafficking organizations and inadequate Canadian enforcement measures. Tariffs will be effective February 4, 2025, unless Canada takes sufficient action to address these issues.

item.title: Memorandum for Immediate Assessment of Aviation Safety
item.description: This memorandum directs the Secretary of Transportation and the Administrator of the FAA to review recent hiring decisions and safety protocols in light of a recent aviation accident, with an emphasis on restoring merit-based recruitment and ensuring aviation safety standards.

item.title: Measures to Address Anti-Semitism in Education
item.description: This executive order reaffirms the previous Executive Order 13899 aimed at combating anti-Semitism, especially in educational settings. It directs federal agencies to report on actions and legal tools available to address incidents of anti-Semitic harassment and violence, particularly following the events of October 7, 2023. It emphasizes the U.S. government's commitment to protecting Jewish students and ensuring compliance with civil rights laws.

item.title: Laken Riley Act Signed into Law
item.description: The Laken Riley Act mandates that the Secretary of Homeland Security detain individuals charged with theft in the United States, along with related provisions.

item.title: Expansion of Migrant Operations Center at Naval Station Guantanamo Bay
item.description: This memorandum directs the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Homeland Security to expand the Migrant Operations Center at Naval Station Guantanamo Bay to its full capacity to provide additional detention space for high-priority criminal aliens and to support related immigration enforcement efforts.

item.title: Establishment of Task Force for America's 250th Independence Anniversary Celebration
item.description: This executive order establishes the White House Task Force on Celebrating America's 250th Birthday, which aims to plan and organize a celebration for the anniversary on July 4, 2026. It includes provisions for the protection of national monuments and reinstates previous executive orders related to this theme.

item.title: Executive Order on Educational Practices and Parental Rights in K-12 Schools
item.description: This executive order aims to address concerns regarding educational practices in K-12 schools, particularly those perceived as indoctrinating students in specific ideologies. It directs federal agencies to develop a strategy to protect parental rights and ensure compliance with existing civil rights laws concerning education funding and practices. Additionally, it reestablishes the President's Advisory 1776 Commission to promote patriotic education and compliance with educational programs about the U.S. Constitution.

item.title: Executive Order on Expanding Educational Choice and Opportunities
item.description: This executive order directs the Secretary of Education to provide guidance to states on using federal funds to support K-12 educational choice initiatives. It encourages educational freedom through discretionary grants and aims to assist low-income families and military families in accessing preferred educational options. Additionally, it mandates a review of options for families eligible for Bureau of Indian Education schools.

item.title: Executive Order on Child Protection from Medical Interventions
item.description: This executive order establishes U.S. policy to prohibit federal funding and support for medical procedures aimed at transitioning the sex of minors, defines terms relevant to such actions, and directs federal agencies to discontinue practices that involve these procedures. It includes directives for data collection on youth with gender dysphoria, changes to health insurance coverage, and enforcement of related laws.

item.title: Order to Reinstate Military Service Members Discharged for COVID-19 Vaccine Refusal
item.description: This executive order mandates the reinstatement of active and reserve military members discharged due to refusal of the COVID-19 vaccine, allowing for back pay and benefits. It also provides provisions for those who voluntarily left the service under similar circumstances to return without impact on their service status. The Secretary of Defense and Secretary of Homeland Security are tasked with implementation and reporting on progress within 60 days.
